messageBody:
Hi Magnus,

On 10/22/06, t703093 <t703093@...> wrote:
> There was 1 failure:
> 1) TestX
> java.lang.Exception: No runnable metods
> at org.junit.internal.runners.TestClassMethodsRunner.testAborted
> (TestClassMethodsRunner.java:42)
> at.....
>
> I assume my classes (both the class X and TestX) must be instrumented
> in some way to make this work? I am totally new to JUnit, so maybe
> You clould show me how to instrument those classes?
>
> Here they are:
>
> public class TestX {
> public static void main (String args[]){
> X y = new X();
> System.out.println(y.met(1));
> }
> }
>
> ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
>
> public class X {
> public int met (int number) {
> int num = number;
> if (num > 1)
> return num*2;
> else{
> return 666;
> }
> }
> }
>
> ////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
>
> maybe I shall put in @Test somewhere in the code above?

Yes, your test class currently doesn't have any test methods. A test
method is a "@Test public void" (non-static), can be named as you
wish, and can throw any exception. For example:

public class TestX {
@Test
public void numbersAboveOneShouldGetDoubled() throws Exception {
assertEquals(4, new X().met(2));
assertEquals(6, new X().met(3));
assertEquals(8, new X().met(4));
}

@Test
public void numbersEqualOrBelowOneShouldYield666() throws Exception {
assertEquals(666, new X().met(1));
assertEquals(666, new X().met(0));
assertEquals(666, new X().met(-4));
}
}


On 10/22/06, t703093 <t703093@...> wrote:
> Both files are placed in a different directory then JUnit directory?
> Is that a problem?

That's not a problem. Directories don't matter as long as all the
compiled .class files are in the class path while running JUnit.
Whether they're all in one directory tree, in two directory trees, in
one directory and three .jar files, doesn't matter.


Lasse
